page.title: 11SAXON ESTATE BOUNDARY: ACTON
page.content: {Saxon Times} The present day boundaries of the nor- thern half of Acton Parish coincide with the Balsdon Estate boundaries described by Aelfflaed, wife of the Saxon hero Byrhtnoth, in her Will. The name still survives today in Balsdon Hall which still has moated enclosures. A boundary point described in the Will as Humelcyrre is remembered today in Humblechar Meadows. The cyrr, Saxon for bend, refers to a sharp change in dir- ection in Chad Brook where it was joined by a tributary from the N.E. Humel means a rounded hillock. In the S.W. of the block an ancient track called Roydon Drift is referred to in this Saxon Will as Roydon. A Gospel Oak stood near the point where the disused railway line meets a by-road.
